channel.title: DJ La Rocca Album Art
channel.description: Hey guys was wondering if I can get some feedback on an album I’m looking to releases sometime within some months or weeks. It will feature new progressive House tracks and possibly other house genres. But I wanted to add aural Flux in there but I’ve already made artwork... would it matter? Or should I just get rid of the artwork? Please give some feedback![image|500x500](upload://qI5WZAvU7txoRddEeHGWBGyUb0V.jpeg)

item.title: DJ La Rocca Album Art
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
+ @DJ_La_Rocca

That’s not quite accurate.

There is the Publishing issue.
The performance (‘the recording’) and the composition are both protected individually under copyright law.

Typically speaking, Publishing rights owners don’t have - or don’t apply - prohibitive license over compositions. You simply make your cover version and pay the required Publishing royalties.

(It’s rare that Publishing rights holders will veto the use. It only really ever happens when the person requesting the rights (wanting to make the cover version) or the intended use is somehow deeply objectionable to the rights owner.)

Read full topic

item.title: DJ La Rocca Album Art
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Not quite.

Parody is when you’re mimicking something comically. (I’m assuming @DJ_La_Rocca’s tutorial videos are sincere, genuine attempts to share how to make certain genres.)

A good example of parody might be those ‘How to make every [insert genre here] track in 2 minutes’ videos. They’re tongue-in-cheek, making fun of the formulaic style of certain genres. Still, they generally mimicking the general style rather than duplicating specific tracks.

If you’re mimicking the general style and not actually using notes from one of their tracks, you’re on safe ground, as you can’t copyright (or protect) a ‘style’.

If you’re using actual notes, then it’s a publishing rights issue, but you could be covered under Fair Use on the grounds of it being for ‘educational purposes’.

Read full topic

item.title: DJ La Rocca Album Art
item.dc:creator: DJ_La_Rocca
item.description:
I screen record my videos and I plan what I’m going to say at those points. So sometimes I record in sections. Then I do voiceovers. It’s more proffesional instead of being on the spot. It’s just easier. My videos are over on the Auxy tutorials thread if u wanna find any inspiration

item.title: DJ La Rocca Album Art
item.dc:creator: xavior
item.description:
I don’t know much about bootlegging, so I can’t really say. I think everyone’s just recommending that you be as safe as possible when it comes to using art from others. Although I haven’t gotten into any legal trouble, that’s the last thing I’d want to happen regarding my music.

Read full topic

item.title: DJ La Rocca Album Art
item.dc:creator: xavior
item.description:
There is a difference when it’s just copy and pasting. You could argue the same to an artist who cuts out pieces of art (from a magazine, let’s say) and makes a new artwork from it. They still used images that aren’t theirs, but they made it into something new.

When it comes to art, the legal logistics are always argued over and finicky. Keep in mind, things change completely when you ask for money using your art. That’s really when it matters.

Read full topic
